title-group.article-title: Educational Outcomes Associated With Providing a Comprehensive Guidelines Program About Nursing Care of Preterm Neonates Receiving Total Parenteral Nutrition

author-notes.corresp: Safy S. Al-Rafay, Assistant Professor of Pediatric Nursing, Ain Shams University, 29 Ahmad Hosni, Nasr City, Cairo 11371, Egypt Email: salrafay@hotmail.com

fn.p: Safy S. Al-Rafay, is an assistant professor of pediatric nursing, Faculty of Nursing, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt.
Sabah S. Al-Sharkawy, is a professor of pediatric nursing, Faculty of Nursing, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt.

abstract.p: Poor understanding or practice of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) causes devastating complications. Therefore, good Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) nursing care for preterm neonates and close monitoring of complications is essential for successful TPN therapy. The study was conducted in NICU at Ain Shams University Hospital in Cairo, Egypt, using a quasi-experimental research design with prepost intervention assessments. Data was collected using a self-administered questionnaire sheet and an observation checklist (prepost format) and developed a comprehensive guidelines program about nursing care of TPN of preterm neonates. Results revealed that the program had a significant positive impact on nurses’ knowledge and practice outcomes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Parenteral nutrition (PN) is a life saving therapy for many infants who are unable to tolerate enteral feedings. It fulfills preterm neonates’ needs for growth and development when their size or conditions preclude enteral feeding (Chaudhari & Kadam, 2006).
Nurses are responsible for the administration of parenteral nutrition and monitoring for fluid and electrolyte imbalance and early signs of infection.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Assessment of preterm neonates’ nutritional status by the critical care nurse and timely intervention by the interdisciplinary health care team optimize infants’ outcomes and transition through their critical care phase (Sole, Klein, & Moseley, 2005).

Therefore, this study evaluates the effect of providing a comprehensive guidelines program about nursing care of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) on the educational outcomes of Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) nurses who take care of preterm neonates.

Good nursing care and close biochemical monitoring are absolutely essential for successful PN therapy (Chaudhari & Kadam, 2006). Neonatologists, surgeons, nurses, nutritional support team, care coordinators, microbiologists or infection control team, clinical chemists, pharmacists, social workers, and psychologists with expertise in infant feeding difficulties constitute health team members who have different roles in PN therapy. Such collaborative care would certainly have better outcomes (Mascarenhas, Kerner, & Stalling, 2000).

Although feeding through the gastrointestinal tract is the preferred route for nutritional management, there are specific conditions when TPN as an adjunctive or sole therapy is necessary (Chaudhari & Kadam, 2006). TPN, also referred to as parenteral nutrition (PN), is provided when the gastrointestinal tract is nonfunctional because of an interruption in its continuity, or because absorptive capacity is impaired (Kozier et al., 2004).

Preterm infants, especially those who have been growth restricted in utero, have fewer nutrient reserves at birth, compared to term infants. In addition, they are subject to physiological and metabolic stresses that can affect their nutritional needs, such as respiratory distress or infection. However, because of the rapidly changing clinical condition of preterm infants, many neonatal intensive care units review and formulate a new PN order on a daily basis. That order takes into account infant’s clinical condition, weight, urine output, and current laboratory data (Peverini, Beach, Wan, & Vyhmeister, 2002).

The solutions used in TPN contain multivitamin mixtures, minerals, and trace elements in addition to glucose (dextrose), which is an important energy source. Lipid is given as a source of essential fatty acids and energy and to provide balance to the nutritional intake. Specialized amino acid solutions are available for use in renal and hepatic failure and for infants. Iron should not be added to lipid-containing solutions (Moore, 2005).

Bhatia and Adamkin (2006) suggested that early amino acids are a very good strategy. They begin with “vanilla” total parenteral nutrition (TPN) as soon as the umbilical venous catheter is inserted. It is a stock solution of 4% amino acids, which only contains amino acids and glucose, and is infused literally from the first hours of life with the intention of providing about 2 g per kilogram per day of protein right from the beginning.

Careless use due to inadequate understanding or poor supervision can result in devastating complications such as septicemia and metabolic imbalances. Such complications can be reduced by meticulous management of PN in response to biochemical abnormalities, nutrition teams, policies to reduce sepsis, and staff training to be more aware of pericardial and pleural effusions (Ahmed, Irwin, & Tuthill, 2004).

Therefore, guidelines for the relative amounts of the various ingredients composing a PN solution must optimize nutritional support while protecting against potentially dangerous values (Peverini et al., 2002).

list-item.p: Research Question 1: To what extent does a comprehensive guidelines program associated with nursing care of preterm neonates who are receiving total parenteral nutrition affect the educational outcomes of the NICU nurses?

sec.title: Hypothesis
sec.p: The study hypothesized that providing a comprehensive guidelines program would improve NICU nurses’ knowledge and practice in administrating and monitoring TPN for the preterm neonates they are caring for.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: A quasi-experimental research design with prepost intervention assessments is used to measure the effect of the implemented guidelines program about nursing care of TPN for NICU nurses on the educational outcomes.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: The study was conducted in the NICU at Ain Shams University Hospital in Cairo, Egypt, which admits in-born and out-born neonates with medical and surgical conditions. It is a three-room NICU; each room accommodates 7 NICU patients. The unit contains a room for preparing TPN, a room for preparing formulas and a store. About 9 to 11 is the daily number of neonates taking TPN during the study.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: All the 40 nurses working in NICU, with different qualifications and years of experience, were included in the study. They were all females and had been working in the setting for at least 3 years.

A consecutive sample of 80 preterm neonates, less than 37 weeks gestational age, was recruited in this study from NICU. The inclusion criteria were preterm neonates with gestational age between 35 and less than 37 weeks, weighing 1,800 grams or more, with a validated order of TPN administered by an intravenous access either peripherally or centrally. Exclusion criteria were preterm babies who were postoperative.

sec.title: Data Collection
sec.p: Researchers designed and used two different tools that included self-administered questionnaire sheet (prepost format), and observation checklist (prepost format).

sec.title: Sociodemographic data
sec.p: Characteristics of the nurse such as age, level of education, years of experience, and attendance of training courses. In addition, characteristics of preterm neonate, such as medical record number, date of birth, age, diagnosis, and weight.

sec.title: Knowledge questionnaire (prepost format)
sec.p: It is used for assessment of nurse’s knowledge about basic principles of total parenteral nutrition. It consisted of eight sections with a total of 35 questions (goals of TPN: 5 questions; indications: 4 questions; components: 4 questions; routes of administration: 6 questions; steps of administration: 2 questions; precautions to follow: 5 questions; monitoring neonates with TPN: 5 questions; and recommended documentation after infusion: 4 questions).

sec.title: Observation Checklist (Prepost Format)
sec.p: This is used to assess each nurse’s performance during preparation and administration of total parenteral nutrition for preterm neonates. It consisted of four parts with a total of 28 questions:

sec.title: Part 1
sec.p: Preparation of TPN: (a) Use the five rights of medication administration and verify rate per hour, (b) maintain strict aseptic technique when handling catheter, dressing changing, tubing, and administrating TPN solution, and (c) monitor fluids and electrolytes, vital signs, and laboratory results.

sec.title: Part 2
sec.p: Technique: (a) Connect the extension tubing or stopcocks to the TPN line, (b) administer via infusion pump adjustment of dripping according to calculation, (c) monitor preterm neonate for unusual response, and (d) apply catheter dressing.

sec.title: Part 3
sec.p: Safe administration: (a) Do: inspect visually for precipitate before administration and periodically during infusion; (b) Do: discard any TPN and tubing more than 24 hr old; (c) Do not: use the TPN line for piggybacking medication and for central venous pressure monitoring; (d) Do not: use the TPN line when blood sampling is needed; and (e) Do not: store TPN in the refrigerator until time of infusion.

sec.title: Part 4
sec.p: Nursing monitoring of TPN complications:

list-item.p: Mechanical and technical monitoring of (a) air embolism, (b) central venous thrombosis, (c) catheter occlusion or semiocclusion, and (d) malposition;
Infections monitoring of (a) catheter site infection, and (b) catheter-related sepsis;

Metabolic monitoring of (a) dextrose-related complications, (b) protein- related complications, (c) lipid-related complications, (d) hepatic effects, (e) electrolyte, and (f) trace elements deficiencies;
Nutritional monitoring of (a) diarrhea, (b) constipation, (c) gastric distention, and (d) dehydration.

sec.title: Educational Guidelines Program
sec.p: The researchers developed and implemented a comprehensive guidelines program about nursing care of TPN for preterm neonates. The program phases were

sec.title: Exploratory phase
sec.p: Baseline assessment for nurses had been done before the development of the program content.

sec.title: Validity and reliability
sec.p: During the program construction phase, the content of nursing care of TPN provided for preterm neonates was based on the identified nurses’ needs, in addition to reviewing related literature (e.g., Elkin, Perry, & Potter, 2007; Moore, 2005; Sole et al., 2005; Williams & Schlenker, 2003). In addition, a group of experts reviewed the program and evaluated for interrater reliability content; they were Consultant Neonatologists and the Head Nurse of the NICU.

sec.title: Implementation phase
sec.p: The intervention program was implemented in a series of four sessions, 4 days a week. These were 2 days in the morning shift (Saturday and Wednesday); and another 2 days in the afternoon shift according to the nurses’ schedule, with a total of 10 hr for each group. Four of these hours were allocated to theoretical content, in two sessions, 2 hr each. This part covered the goals of TPN, its indications, components, routes, and steps of administration, precautions to follow, monitoring for neonates with TPN, and the recommended documentation after infusion. The practical part of the program was provided through two sessions, 3 hr each, for a total of 6 hr. This part covered training on the technique of TPN, its safe administration, monitoring of complications such as mechanical and technical, infections, metabolic, and nutritional complications.

During the implementation stage of the program, participant nurses were divided into eight groups of five nurses each, according to their schedule. After clarifying the objectives of the study, a simple introduction was illustrated to the participant nurses (The study period spanned from June to October 2007).

The program was initiated by the theoretical part, followed by the practical part. Teaching strategies included small group discussions, demonstrations, and bedside nursing rounds for correction of mistakes on the spot. Audiovisual media used included a movie about administration of TPN, printed handouts rich in colored pictures and boards. In addition, real equipment and machines needed for administration of total parenteral nutrition such as infusion pump, bacterial filter, Y-connection, scalp vein set, IV infusion set and bottles of lipid emulsion, amino acid, dextrose, and electrolytes were actually used for the training. All materials were revised after the practical sessions to give the participant nurses the chance for repracticing in the presence of the researchers to ensure maximum efficiency.

sec.title: Evaluation phase
sec.p: The target outcome of this study focused on appraisal of nurses’ knowledge and practice that were assessed after the program using the same tools of the pretest.

Self-administered questionnaire sheets were completed by nurses in the NICU independently. According to the designed model key answer, the knowledge of nurses was categorized into two categories, either “unsatisfactory” when the total score obtained was less than 75%, or “satisfactory” when 75% or more from the total grade of the provided questionnaire.

The observation checklists were completed, for assessment of nurses’ performance during provision of care for preterm neonates. The practice of the nurse was categorized into “adequate” once the nurse had 80% or more of the total marks, or “inadequate” when less than 80%.
Knowledge and practice were evaluated twice for each participant nurse, with two different preterm neonates: before and after the exposure to providing the comprehensive guidelines program about TPN.

sec.title: Pilot Study
sec.p: Five pilot participant-nurses were asked to answer the questionnaire. They were observed during caring of preterm neonates receiving TPN to appraise the applicability of the tools related to their knowledge and practice. Modifications such as exclusion criteria of neonates and questions related to recommended documentation were added according to the pilot results.

sec.title: Ethical Considerations
sec.p: Ethical issues in this study involved the assurance of confidentiality and anonymity for the participant nurses. All participants and mothers of preterm neonates were informed about the purpose and design of the study. Official approvals to conduct the study were obtained from the Ethical and Research committees as well as the supervisor general and the chairperson of the NICU. They recommended that the study should not include preterm neonates less than 35 weeks gestational age, or postoperative neonates because of their critical conditions. And, all 40 NICU nurses should be included in the study.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Data entry and statistical analysis were done using SPSS 13.0 statistical software package. Quantitative continuous data were compared using the nonparametric Mann-Whitney test since normal distribution of the data could not be assumed. Qualitative categorical variables were compared using chi-square test. Whenever the expected values in one or more of the cells in a 2 × 2 tables is less than 5, Fisher exact test was used instead. Statistical significance was considered at p value <.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Table 1 shows that slightly less than half of the nurses in the study sample were in the age group 25 to less than 30 years (45.0%) and the majority (70.0%) have a nursing school diploma. As for experience, two fifth (40.0%) of them have less than 5 years of experience. As the table indicates, only four nurses (10.0%) have previously attended training courses.

caption.p: Sociodemographic Characteristics of Nurses in the Study Sample (n = 40)

sec.p: Before implementation of the guidelines program, Table 2 indicates that nurses’ knowledge scores were generally low, especially in relation to goals, indications, and components of TPN and precautions to follow. Conversely, after application of the guidelines, statistically significant improvements were revealed in most areas of knowledge as well as the total (p < .001). The highest relative increases in the scores were related to goals, indications, and components of TPN. Meanwhile, no statistically significant increases were noticed in the scores of knowledge related to monitoring and documentation.

caption.p: Prepost Changes in Nurses’ Knowledge Scores

sec.p: Concerning nurses’ practice related to TPN, Table 3 shows that the scores of practice were higher for administration, compared to monitoring of complications before implementation of the guidelines. After application of the guidelines, statistically significant improvements were noticed in all areas of administration and most areas of monitoring of complications. Also, the total practice score increased from 21.8 ± 2.6 to 25.8 ± 1.5 (p < .001). The areas of management of metabolic and infectious complications show improvements but do not reach statistically significant differences.

caption.p: Prepost Changes in Nurses’ Practice Scores

sec.p: Overall, as Table 4 illustrates, only one tenth of the nurses have satisfactory knowledge at the pretest. This percentage rose to 90.0% at the posttest (p < .001). As regards total practice, the pretest is adequate among 67.5% of the nurses, whereas all of them (100.0%) have adequate practice at the posttest (p < .001). The practice related to TPN administration increased at the posttest but did not reach statistical significance (p = .49).

caption.p: Prepost Changes in Nurses’ Knowledge and Practice

tr.th: Changes in nurses’ knowledge and practice

tr.td: Practice of monitoring of TPN complications

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The desire for evidence-based clinical guidelines for nutritional support of the preterm infant has been identified. In addition, consistent, comprehensive, multidisciplinary appraisal of practice is an integral component of improving nutrition outcomes in the neonatal population. (Kuzma-O’Reilly et al., 2003).

At the beginning of this study, a pretest is applied to assess the knowledge and practice of participating nurses, in addition to their sociodemographic data, to develop specifically targeted comprehensive guidelines program about total parenteral nutrition according to their identified knowledge and practice deficits. The study findings indicated low knowledge scores before implementation of the guidelines. This is particularly evident as regards the components of TPN and precautions to follow. These two areas were of major importance since time is critical for the decision to start TPN in preterm neonates. In this regard, Irving, Simone, Hicks, and Verger (2000) clarified that although feeding through the gastrointestinal tract is the preferred route for nutritional management, there were specific instances when PN as adjunctive or sole therapy is necessary to meet nutritional needs.

Furthermore, regarding route of administration of TPN, nurses should always update their knowledge since research always adds new evidence in this area. This might explain the low level of knowledge scores demonstrated among the present study nurses. In congruence with this, Marshall and West (2004) emphasized that nursing practice was inconsistent within and between intensive care units (ICUs) and this could be linked to the shortage of reliable and valid research into the many issues associated with the effective delivery of enteral and parenteral nutrition.

Concerning knowledge about the precautions nurses should consider while administering TPN, Baird (2001) pointed to a major risk that is often overlooked by nurses. Preterm neonates have low antioxidant reserves and, like sick term infants, typically suffer significant oxidative stress. Therefore, by protecting these infusates from light, bedside nurses can reduce the amount of hydroperoxides infused and protect NICU patients from the associated risks.

On the other hand, nurses have very high knowledge scores regarding monitoring neonates with TPN, even before implementation of the guidelines. This high level of knowledge could be related to the fact that in real-life situation, the major role of the nurse is to monitor the preterm neonates with TPN for most of the time of the shift. On the same lines, Ista and Joosten (2005) emphasized that critical care nurses play an important role in feeding of critically ill children and preterm neonates. They should be knowledgeable about many procedures and caregiving interventions, such as observation and care of the neonate during administration of nutrition, whether enteral or parenteral.

The highest relative increases in the scores were related to goals and components of TPN. Meanwhile, no statistically significant increases were noticed in the scores of knowledge related to monitoring and documentation. Overall, the majority of the nurses have unsatisfactory knowledge at the pretest. After application of the TPN guidelines program, statistically significant improvements were revealed in most areas of knowledge and in total knowledge. In congruence with these findings, Brown, Garrison, and Hutchison (2007) reported about the effect of implementation of an interactive computerized PN worksheet that resulted in improvement of the knowledge of NICU, pediatric residents, and neonatal nurse practitioners and led to statistically significant reduction in the error rates in both groups.

The present study also assessed nurses’ practice related to TPN. The results demonstrated relatively high scores for administration of TPN and monitoring of complications related to mechanical and gastrointestinal complications. The high scores of these two areas were quite plausible given the clear related policies and procedures and the fact that this is the daily routine work of these nurses. The low scores were related to management of metabolic and infectious complications of TPN before implementation of the program. Low scores might be explained by both lack of knowledge and the infrequent occurrence of such complications, which might limit nurses’ related experience. However, these complications are always a threat to preterm infants and can occur at any time and nurses should be prepared and should be capable of dealing with such complications. In this respect, Johnson and Sexton (2006) mentioned that complications of PN included infection, accidental damage to, or removal of, the line, and cholestatic liver disease. Moreover, Chaudhari and Kadam (2006) reported that TPN should only be used in units where there is full-time medical coverage, trained nursing staff who can be relied on for proper care of IV lines, facilities to prepare solutions correctly under laminar flow hood, appropriate laboratory backup, and appropriate equipment including infusion pumps.

Similarly, Pérez-Navero et al. (2005), in an epidemiologic study of artificial nutrition in critically ill pediatric patients, reported that PN complications consisted of catheter-related infection, thrombophlebitis, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypertriglyceridemia. Furthermore, Camara (2001) reported about the use of peripherally inserted central catheters (PICC lines) as means of administration of and assuring better parenteral nutrition to infants. Although there are many benefits to the use of these catheters, physicians and nurses within the NICU must remain acutely aware of the risks involved with placement of PICC lines so that complications can be minimized. Prevention of sepsis in neonates is always a priority and several measures can be implemented to reduce this risk, including scrupulous aseptic technique, knowledgeable selection of the insertion site, and consistent daily care. Other complications such as thrombosis, extravascular collection of fluid due to catheter migration or blockage, vessel perforation, and line leakage are all concerns when using this valuable tool in the care of preterm neonates. Therefore, Hulst, Joosten, Tibboel, and Van Goudoever (2006) stressed that meticulous routine nutritional assessment and monitoring are essential to prevent inadequate nutritional supply and its potentially harmful consequences.

After application of the guidelines program, statistically significant improvements were noticed in all areas of TPN administration, where maximal scores are reached at the posttest. The scores of all areas of monitoring of complications increased at the posttest; however, the increases in the areas of monitoring of metabolic and infectious complications did not reach statistically significant differences. This might be due to the relatively higher pretest scores in these two areas and could be attributed to the seriousness of related complications. Overall, all nurses had adequate practice at the posttest, compared to about two thirds in the pretest. The seriousness of infectious complications were reported by Irving (2001) that preterm neonates react to infection by having increased apneas and bradycardias with associated saturation drops, an increased oxygen requirement, and/or temperature instability. This emphasized that every attempt should be done by NICU nurses to apply aseptic technique during preparation and administration of TPN for preterm neonates based on the established guidelines program.

Embedding the change in the system is also an important factor that guarantees its success. Implementation of the TPN guidelines program could not be achieved without looking at organizational climate and leadership issues. These factors were taken into account in the present study and certainly contributed to the positive impact of the applied guidelines. In agreement with this, Pollack and Koch (2003) demonstrated a lower incidence of complications in NICUs with better overall scores for leadership, coordination, and conflict resolution. Therefore, Rikli et al. (2006) concluded that implementation of the potentially better practice had a positive influence on nurse satisfaction.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: One of the strengths of the study is that physicians and nurses showed appropriate cooperation and participation. The limitation of the study is the lack of storage places to store the media used during the program and in each session the researchers held full responsibility in carrying and storing their heavy materials for providing the program.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The study demonstrated that implementation of a TPN guidelines program had a significant positive impact on NICU nurses’ knowledge and practice and led to higher educational and practical outcomes during administration and monitoring of TPN complications among preterm neonates. The used Simulation Training seems to be safe and life saving for NICU preterm neonates.

sec.title: Recommendations
sec.p: Based on the study findings, it is recommended to offer regular educational programs and in-service training that target NICU nurses in all shifts. The developed program should be implemented on a wider scale and for longer time to assess long-term impact. Participation of setting leaders in every step of development and implementation is strongly recommended to provide an organizational climate that helps success of the program.

sec.title: Implications for Practice
sec.p: Nurses in NICU have a unique position in caring for preterm neonates and typically have an important impact on administrating TPN, whether it is delivered by peripheral or central vein access. Researchers designed the prepost intervention assessment formats to focus on the theoretical and practical requirements of the NICU nurses. Researchers also implemented the comprehensive guidelines program about nursing care of TPN of preterm neonates started by the theoretical part; it was a helpful technique for alerting the participant nurses about goals, indications, components, routes, steps, and precautions and recommended documentation of TPN administration. The target of the practical part is an overall training for nurses to eliminate the weak points related to safe administration of TPN, monitoring of complications with focus on factors related to mechanical, technical, infections, metabolic, and nutritional complications.

Ultimately, researchers encouraged nurses to ask for more explanations for vague points, and the researchers were always available to answer any questions, and to make sure of their feedback. Teaching strategies included demonstrations as well as nursing rounds for correcting mistakes on the spot. Researchers used a film about administration of TPN, and boards. Moreover, essential real equipment and machines for administration of TPN were used during the training. Handouts were distributed to the nurses to serve as references and proper guidance. Findings assured the main outcome of the researchers as pediatric educators, statistically significant improvements in most areas of total knowledge, and practice of NICU nurses after following of the TPN guidelines program.

ack.p: Editing for this article and related content were revised by Basem Al-Ganzory, bachelor of English, Ain Shams University. Data statistical analysis was supported by Eslam Al-Ganzory, demonstrator of engineering, Ain Shams University. The authors would like to thank their efforts.

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interests with respect to the research, authorship and/or publication of this article.
The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
